events.text_segment:
I remained motionless. The thunder ceased; but the rain still continued, and the scene was enveloped in an impenetrable darkness. I revolved in my mind the events which I had until now sought to forget: the whole train of my progress toward the creation; the appearance of the works of my own hands at my bedside; its departure. Two years had now nearly elapsed since the night on which he first received life; and was this his first crime? Alas! I had turned loose into the world a depraved wretch, whose delight was in carnage and misery; had he not murdered my brother?
No one can conceive the anguish I suffered during the remainder of the night, which I spent, cold and wet, in the open air. But I did not feel the inconvenience of the weather; my imagination was busy in scenes of evil and despair. I considered the being whom I had cast among mankind, and endowed with the will and power to effect purposes of horror, such as the deed which he had now done, nearly in the light of my own vampire, my own spirit let loose from the grave, and forced to destroy all that was dear to me.
Day dawned; and I directed my steps towards the town. The gates were open, and I hastened to my father’s house. My first thought was to discover what I knew of the murderer, and cause instant pursuit to be made. But I paused when I reflected on the story that I had to tell. A being whom I myself had formed, and endued with life, had met me at midnight among the precipices of an inaccessible mountain. I remembered also the nervous fever with which I had been seized just at the time that I dated my creation, and which would give an air of delirium to a tale otherwise so utterly improbable. I well knew that if any other had communicated such a relation to me, I should have looked upon it as the ravings of insanity. Besides, the strange nature of the animal would elude all pursuit, even if I were so far credited as to persuade my relatives to commence it. And then of what use would be pursuit? Who could arrest a creature capable of scaling the overhanging sides of Mont Salêve? These reflections determined me, and I resolved to remain silent.
It was about five in the morning when I entered my father’s house.

events.title: Reunion with Ernest and the Shocking Accusation of Justine Moritz
detailed_summary: Victor instructs the servants not to disturb the family and waits in the library.
He reflects on the six years since he last saw his father in that room and gazes at portraits of his mother and William, tears flowing for his brother.
Ernest enters, welcoming Victor sadly, wishing he had arrived earlier during happier times, and expressing hope that Victor can comfort their father and Elizabeth.
Ernest mentions Elizabeth's self-accusations regarding William's death.
As Victor tries to comfort Ernest and inquires about his father and Elizabeth, Ernest reveals that the murderer has been discovered.
Victor is incredulous, having seen the Creature free the previous night, but Ernest clarifies that the discovery has only deepened their misery.
Ernest names Justine Moritz as the accused, shocking Victor, and explains that despite initial disbelief, circumstances and Justine's confused behavior have convinced many of her guilt.
He recounts that the miniature of Victor's mother was found in Justine's pocket after she fell ill following the murder, leading to her arrest.

events.text_segment:
I told the servants not to disturb the family, and went into the library to attend their usual hour of rising.
Six years had elapsed, passed in a dream but for one indelible trace, and I stood in the same place where I had last embraced my father before my departure for Ingolstadt. Beloved and venerable parent! He still remained to me. I gazed on the picture of my mother, which stood over the mantel-piece. It was an historical subject, painted at my father’s desire, and represented Caroline Beaufort in an agony of despair, kneeling by the coffin of her dead father. Her garb was rustic, and her cheek pale; but there was an air of dignity and beauty, that hardly permitted the sentiment of pity. Below this picture was a miniature of William; and my tears flowed when I looked upon it. While I was thus engaged, Ernest entered: he had heard me arrive, and hastened to welcome me: “Welcome, my dearest Victor,” said he. “Ah! I wish you had come three months ago, and then you would have found us all joyous and delighted. You come to us now to share a misery which nothing can alleviate; yet your presence will, I hope, revive our father, who seems sinking under his misfortune; and your persuasions will induce poor Elizabeth to cease her vain and tormenting self-accusations.—Poor William! he was our darling and our pride!”
Tears, unrestrained, fell from my brother’s eyes; a sense of mortal agony crept over my frame. Before, I had only imagined the wretchedness of my desolated home; the reality came on me as a new, and a not less terrible, disaster. I tried to calm Ernest; I enquired more minutely concerning my father, and here I named my cousin.
“She most of all,” said Ernest, “requires consolation; she accused herself of having caused the death of my brother, and that made her very wretched. But since the murderer has been discovered—”
“The murderer discovered! Good God! how can that be? who could attempt to pursue him? It is impossible; one might as well try to overtake the winds, or confine a mountain-stream with a straw. I saw him too; he was free last night!”
“I do not know what you mean,” replied my brother, in accents of wonder, “but to us the discovery we have made completes our misery. No one would believe it at first; and even now Elizabeth will not be convinced, notwithstanding all the evidence. Indeed, who would credit that Justine Moritz, who was so amiable, and fond of all the family, could suddenly become so capable of so frightful, so appalling a crime?”
“Justine Moritz! Poor, poor girl, is she the accused? But it is wrongfully; every one knows that; no one believes it, surely, Ernest?”
“No one did at first; but several circumstances came out, that have almost forced conviction upon us; and her own behaviour has been so confused, as to add to the evidence of facts a weight that, I fear, leaves no hope for doubt. But she will be tried today, and you will then hear all.”
He then related that, the morning on which the murder of poor William had been discovered, Justine had been taken ill, and confined to her bed for several days. During this interval, one of the servants, happening to examine the apparel she had worn on the night of the murder, had discovered in her pocket the picture of my mother, which had been judged to be the temptation of the murderer. The servant instantly showed it to one of the others, who, without saying a word to any of the family, went to a magistrate; and, upon their deposition, Justine was apprehended. On being charged with the fact, the poor girl confirmed the suspicion in a great measure by her extreme confusion of manner.

You come to us now to share in a grief that nothing can alleviate; yet your presence will, I hope, revive our father, who seems overcome by his misfortune, and your efforts will persuade poor Elizabeth to stop her futile and agonizing self-reproach.—Poor William! he was our darling and our pride!" Tears flowed freely from my brother's eyes, and a sense of mortal pain crept over me. Previously, I had only imagined the misery of my devastated home; the reality descended upon me as a new and equally dreadful catastrophe. I tried to calm Ernest; I inquired more specifically about my father and mentioned my cousin. "She most of all," said Ernest, "needs comfort; she blamed herself for causing my brother's death, and that made her very unhappy. But since the murderer has been discovered—" "The murderer discovered! Good God! how can that be? who could possibly catch him? It is impossible; you might as well try to catch the wind or confine a mountain stream with a piece of straw. I saw him myself last night! he was free!" "I do not know what you mean," replied my brother, with a look of astonishment, "but for us the discovery we have made only deepens our sorrow. No one believed it at first; and even now Elizabeth is not convinced, despite all the evidence. Indeed, who would believe that Justine Moritz, who was so pleasant and loved by the entire family, could suddenly be capable of such a terrible, so shocking a crime?" "Justine Moritz! Poor, poor girl, is she the one accused? But it must be wrong; everyone knows that; surely no one believes it, Ernest?" "No one did initially," he replied, "but several circumstances have come to light that have almost compelled us to believe it; and her own behavior has been so confused as to add such weight to the evidence of facts that, I fear, leaves no room for doubt. But she will be tried today, and you will then hear everything." He then recounted that, on the morning poor William's murder was found, Justine had become ill and remained in bed for several days. During this period, one of the servants, happening to examine the clothes she had worn the night of the murder, discovered in her pocket the portrait of my mother, which was thought to be the murderer's motive. The servant immediately showed it to another, who, without saying anything to the family, went to a magistrate; and based on their testimony, Justine was apprehended. When confronted with the accusation, the poor girl greatly confirmed the suspicion through her extreme confusion in manner.

detailed_summary: Despite Ernest's account, Victor vehemently asserts Justine's innocence, stating he knows the true murderer.

events.text_segment:
This was a strange tale, but it did not shake my faith; and I replied earnestly, “You are all mistaken; I know the murderer. Justine, poor, good Justine, is innocent.”
At that instant my father entered. I saw unhappiness deeply impressed on his countenance, but he endeavoured to welcome me cheerfully; and, after we had exchanged our mournful greeting, would have introduced some other topic than that of our disaster, had not Ernest exclaimed, “Good God, papa! Victor says that he knows who was the murderer of poor William.”
“We do also, unfortunately,” replied my father, “for indeed I had rather have been for ever ignorant than have discovered so much depravity and ungratitude in one I valued so highly.”
“My dear father, you are mistaken; Justine is innocent.”
“If she is, God forbid that she should suffer as guilty. She is to be tried today, and I hope, I sincerely hope, that she will be acquitted.”
This speech calmed me. I was firmly convinced in my own mind that Justine, and indeed every human being, was guiltless of this murder. I had no fear, therefore, that any circumstantial evidence could be brought forward strong enough to convict her. My tale was not one to announce publicly; its astounding horror would be looked upon as madness by the vulgar. Did any one indeed exist, except I, the creator, who would believe, unless his senses convinced him, in the existence of the living monument of presumption and rash ignorance which I had let loose upon the world?
We were soon joined by Elizabeth. Time had altered her since I last beheld her; it had endowed her with loveliness surpassing the beauty of her childish years. There was the same candour, the same vivacity, but it was allied to an expression more full of sensibility and intellect. She welcomed me with the greatest affection. “Your arrival, my dear cousin,” said she, “fills me with hope. You perhaps will find some means to justify my poor guiltless Justine. Alas! who is safe, if she be convicted of crime? I rely on her innocence as certainly as I do upon my own. Our misfortune is doubly hard to us; we have not only lost that lovely darling boy, but this poor girl, whom I sincerely love, is to be torn away by even a worse fate. If she is condemned, I never shall know joy more. But she will not, I am sure she will not; and then I shall be happy again, even after the sad death of my little William.”
“She is innocent, my Elizabeth,” said I, “and that shall be proved; fear nothing, but let your spirits be cheered by the assurance of her acquittal.”
“How kind and generous you are! every one else believes in her guilt, and that made me wretched, for I knew that it was impossible: and to see every one else prejudiced in so deadly a manner rendered me hopeless and despairing.” She wept.
“Dearest niece,” said my father, “dry your tears. If she is, as you believe, innocent, rely on the justice of our laws, and the activity with which I shall prevent the slightest shadow of partiality.”

events.title: Prelude to a Travesty: Victor's Anguish and Justine's Composure
detailed_summary: The narrator, Victor, endured profound suffering while awaiting the trial, considering himself responsible for the potential deaths of two innocent people: the murdered child, William, and Justine.
He felt immense guilt, wishing he could confess to William's murder, but knew such a confession would be dismissed as the ravings of a madman and would not prevent Justine's condemnation.
Justine appeared composed in mourning attire, her inherent attractiveness enhanced by the solemnity of her emotions.

Despite being the subject of widespread public condemnation and execration, she displayed an outward confidence in her innocence, though this tranquility was evidently a forced effort to appear courageous, as her previous confusion had been used against her.

Upon entering the courtroom, she scanned the crowd and quickly located Victor's family; a fleeting tear appeared but she quickly regained her composure, her expression of sorrowful affection seemingly confirming her innocence.

events.text_segment:
We passed a few sad hours until eleven o’clock, when the trial was to commence. My father and the rest of the family being obliged to attend as witnesses, I accompanied them to the court. During the whole of this wretched mockery of justice I suffered living torture. It was to be decided whether the result of my curiosity and lawless devices would cause the death of two of my fellow beings: one a smiling babe full of innocence and joy, the other far more dreadfully murdered, with every aggravation of infamy that could make the murder memorable in horror. Justine also was a girl of merit and possessed qualities which promised to render her life happy; now all was to be obliterated in an ignominious grave, and I the cause! A thousand times rather would I have confessed myself guilty of the crime ascribed to Justine, but I was absent when it was committed, and such a declaration would have been considered as the ravings of a madman and would not have exculpated her who suffered through me.
The appearance of Justine was calm. She was dressed in mourning, and her countenance, always engaging, was rendered, by the solemnity of her feelings, exquisitely beautiful. Yet she appeared confident in innocence and did not tremble, although gazed on and execrated by thousands, for all the kindness which her beauty might otherwise have excited was obliterated in the minds of the spectators by the imagination of the enormity she was supposed to have committed. She was tranquil, yet her tranquillity was evidently constrained; and as her confusion had before been adduced as a proof of her guilt, she worked up her mind to an appearance of courage. When she entered the court she threw her eyes round it and quickly discovered where we were seated. A tear seemed to dim her eye when she saw us, but she quickly recovered herself, and a look of sorrowful affection seemed to attest her utter guiltlessness.

events.title: The Weight of Evidence: Justine's Trial Commences
detailed_summary: After the prosecutor formally stated the charges against Justine, a series of witnesses were summoned to testify.
A collection of unsettling facts was presented, damaging to Justine's case, which would have troubled anyone not possessing Victor's certainty of her innocence.
Evidence showed she had been out for the entire night when William was murdered.
A market-woman reported seeing Justine near the location where William's body was later discovered, noting her strange demeanor and confused, unintelligible responses when questioned.
Justine returned to the Frankenstein household around eight in the morning, claiming she had been searching for William and anxiously asking if there was any news of him.
When confronted with William's body, she experienced violent hysterics and remained bedridden for several days.

The locket, discovered in Justine's pocket by a servant, was then presented as evidence; Elizabeth, her voice trembling, confirmed it was the same locket she had placed around William's neck just an hour before he went missing, causing a wave of horror and outrage to sweep through the courtroom.

Upon her return around nine o'clock, she was informed by a man that a child was missing, which alarmed her.

She remained awake for most of the night, possibly dozing briefly before being awakened by footsteps at dawn, whereupon she left to continue her search for William.
She insisted that if she had been near the location of William's body, it was entirely without her knowledge.

events.text_segment:
Justine was called on for her defence. As the trial had proceeded, her countenance had altered. Surprise, horror, and misery were strongly expressed. Sometimes she struggled with her tears, but when she was desired to plead, she collected her powers and spoke in an audible although variable voice.
“God knows,” she said, “how entirely I am innocent. But I do not pretend that my protestations should acquit me; I rest my innocence on a plain and simple explanation of the facts which have been adduced against me, and I hope the character I have always borne will incline my judges to a favourable interpretation where any circumstance appears doubtful or suspicious.”
She then related that, by the permission of Elizabeth, she had passed the evening of the night on which the murder had been committed at the house of an aunt at Chêne, a village situated at about a league from Geneva. On her return, at about nine o’clock, she met a man who asked her if she had seen anything of the child who was lost. She was alarmed by this account and passed several hours in looking for him, when the gates of Geneva were shut, and she was forced to remain several hours of the night in a barn belonging to a cottage, being unwilling to call up the inhabitants, to whom she was well known. Most of the night she spent here watching; towards morning she believed that she slept for a few minutes; some steps disturbed her, and she awoke. It was dawn, and she quitted her asylum, that she might again endeavour to find my brother. If she had gone near the spot where his body lay, it was without her knowledge. That she had been bewildered when questioned by the market-woman was not surprising, since she had passed a sleepless night and the fate of poor William was yet uncertain. Concerning the picture she could give no account.
“I know,” continued the unhappy victim, “how heavily and fatally this one circumstance weighs against me, but I have no power of explaining it; and when I have expressed my utter ignorance, I am only left to conjecture concerning the probabilities by which it might have been placed in my pocket. But here also I am checked. I believe that I have no enemy on earth, and none surely would have been so wicked as to destroy me wantonly. Did the murderer place it there? I know of no opportunity afforded him for so doing; or, if I had, why should he have stolen the jewel, to part with it again so soon?
“I commit my cause to the justice of my judges, yet I see no room for hope. I beg permission to have a few witnesses examined concerning my character, and if their testimony shall not overweigh my supposed guilt, I must be condemned, although I would pledge my salvation on my innocence.”

Justine then described that, with Elizabeth's permission, she had spent the night of the murder at her aunt's home in Chêne, a village about a league from Geneva. When she returned around nine o'clock, a man asked her if she had seen the missing child, which worried her. She spent hours searching for him, and when the city gates closed, she was forced to stay in a barn rather than disturb people she knew. She stayed awake most of the night, possibly dozing near morning until footsteps woke her. At dawn, she left to keep searching for William. If she had come near where the boy's body was found, it was accidental. She was confused when questioned by a market-woman, which was understandable after a sleepless, stressful night. She could not explain how the picture came into her possession. She admitted this was a serious point against her, but she was clueless as to how it happened. She wondered if the real murderer planted it, though she couldn't see how or why. Justine put her fate in the hands of the judges, saw little hope, and requested witnesses be called to vouch for her character, insisting she was innocent even if the evidence seemed otherwise.

events.title: Elizabeth's Ardent Defense: A Testament to Justine's Virtue
detailed_summary: Several individuals who had known Justine for many years were called to testify, and they spoke positively of her.
However, their fear and revulsion towards the crime she was accused of made them hesitant and ineffective in their support.
Elizabeth, witnessing this last resource—Justine's excellent character and blameless conduct—failing the accused, became violently agitated and requested permission to address the court.
She identified herself as the murdered child's cousin, or rather his sister due to their shared upbringing, acknowledging the potential indecency of her intervention.
Elizabeth stated her motivation was to prevent a fellow human being from dying due to the cowardice of her supposed friends and wished to share her knowledge of Justine's character.
She affirmed her deep familiarity with Justine, having lived with her for extended periods, during which Justine always appeared to be the most kind-hearted and benevolent person.
Elizabeth recounted Justine's devoted nursing of Madame Frankenstein during her final illness and her subsequent care for her own mother, which elicited admiration from all who knew her.
She emphasized that Justine was beloved by the entire Frankenstein family and had treated William with the affection of a devoted mother.
Elizabeth then unequivocally declared her firm belief in Justine's complete innocence, despite all the evidence presented against her.

She argued that Justine had no motive for such a crime and, concerning the locket which was the main proof, stated she would have gladly given it to Justine had she desired it, because of her high esteem and value for her.

Several witnesses were called who had known her for many years, and they spoke well of her; but fear and hatred of the crime of which they supposed her guilty rendered them timorous and unwilling to come forward. Elizabeth saw even this last resource, her excellent dispositions and irreproachable conduct, about to fail the accused, when, although violently agitated, she desired permission to address the court.
“I am,” said she, “the cousin of the unhappy child who was murdered, or rather his sister, for I was educated by and have lived with his parents ever since and even long before his birth. It may therefore be judged indecent in me to come forward on this occasion, but when I see a fellow creature about to perish through the cowardice of her pretended friends, I wish to be allowed to speak, that I may say what I know of her character. I am well acquainted with the accused. I have lived in the same house with her, at one time for five and at another for nearly two years. During all that period she appeared to me the most amiable and benevolent of human creatures. She nursed Madame Frankenstein, my aunt, in her last illness, with the greatest affection and care and afterwards attended her own mother during a tedious illness, in a manner that excited the admiration of all who knew her, after which she again lived in my uncle’s house, where she was beloved by all the family. She was warmly attached to the child who is now dead and acted towards him like a most affectionate mother. For my own part, I do not hesitate to say that, notwithstanding all the evidence produced against her, I believe and rely on her perfect innocence. She had no temptation for such an action; as to the bauble on which the chief proof rests, if she had earnestly desired it, I should have willingly given it to her, so much do I esteem and value her.”

events.title: Verdict and Despair: Justine Condemned, Victor Overwhelmed by Guilt
detailed_summary: While Elizabeth's passionate speech elicited a murmur of approval for her noble intervention, it paradoxically intensified the public's outrage against Justine, who was now accused of heinous ingratitude.
Justine wept as Elizabeth spoke but offered no response.

Victor experienced extreme agitation and anguish throughout the trial, fully believing in Justine's innocence and convinced that the demonic creature he created had not only murdered his brother but also framed an innocent person for the crime.
Unable to bear the horror of the situation and perceiving from the crowd's reaction and the judges' expressions that Justine was already condemned, Victor fled the courtroom in agony.
He felt his own suffering was greater than Justine's; she was sustained by her innocence, whereas he was tormented by the fangs of remorse.
After a night of unmitigated wretchedness, Victor returned to the court, his lips and throat parched, too afraid to inquire about the verdict.
An officer, recognizing him and discerning the reason for his visit, informed him that the ballots had all been cast against Justine: she was condemned.

events.title: The Unthinkable Confession: Victor's Agony and Elizabeth's Disillusionment
detailed_summary: Victor found himself unable to articulate the depth of the heart-wrenching despair he experienced upon learning of Justine's fate.
The individual who informed him of the condemnation added that Justine had confessed to her guilt.

This person commented that such a confession was hardly necessary given the seemingly obvious nature of the case, but expressed satisfaction, noting that judges are generally reluctant to condemn based solely on circumstantial evidence, no matter how compelling.

This news of a confession struck Victor as bizarre and unexpected, making him question his own perceptions and sanity, wondering if he was as mad as the world would deem him if he revealed his suspicions about the true murderer.
He hurried home, where Elizabeth anxiously awaited the news.

Victor informed her of the decision, remarking with bitterness that the justice system would rather see ten innocents suffer than let one guilty person escape, and then revealed that Justine had confessed.
This disclosure was a devastating blow to Elizabeth, who had steadfastly believed in Justine's innocence.

In her despair, Elizabeth questioned how she could ever again trust in human goodness, lamenting how Justine, whom she loved and esteemed like a sister, could feign such innocence only to betray them, and commit murder despite her apparently gentle and guileless nature.

events.text_segment:
I cannot pretend to describe what I then felt. I had before experienced sensations of horror, and I have endeavoured to bestow upon them adequate expressions, but words cannot convey an idea of the heart-sickening despair that I then endured. The person to whom I addressed myself added that Justine had already confessed her guilt. “That evidence,” he observed, “was hardly required in so glaring a case, but I am glad of it, and, indeed, none of our judges like to condemn a criminal upon circumstantial evidence, be it ever so decisive.”
This was strange and unexpected intelligence; what could it mean? Had my eyes deceived me? And was I really as mad as the whole world would believe me to be if I disclosed the object of my suspicions? I hastened to return home, and Elizabeth eagerly demanded the result.
“My cousin,” replied I, “it is decided as you may have expected; all judges had rather that ten innocent should suffer than that one guilty should escape. But she has confessed.”
This was a dire blow to poor Elizabeth, who had relied with firmness upon Justine’s innocence. “Alas!” said she. “How shall I ever again believe in human goodness? Justine, whom I loved and esteemed as my sister, how could she put on those smiles of innocence only to betray? Her mild eyes seemed incapable of any severity or guile, and yet she has committed a murder.”

events.title: Prison Visit: Justine Reveals Her Coerced Confession
detailed_summary: Shortly thereafter, they learned that Justine, the condemned victim, wished to see Elizabeth.
Victor's father expressed reservations about Elizabeth going but ultimately left the decision to her own judgment and feelings.
Elizabeth resolved to visit Justine, even believing her guilty, and insisted that Victor accompany her, a prospect that was torturous for him, yet he felt unable to refuse.
They entered the somber prison cell to find Justine sitting on straw, manacled, with her head on her knees.
Justine rose upon their entry and, once they were alone, threw herself at Elizabeth's feet, weeping bitterly, and Elizabeth wept with her.
Elizabeth lamented that Justine's supposed guilt had deprived her of her final solace—the belief in Justine's innocence—making her current misery even greater.
Justine, her voice choked with sobs, asked if Elizabeth too believed her to be so wicked and had joined her accusers.

Elizabeth urged Justine to rise if she was innocent, affirming that she had believed her guiltless despite all evidence until she heard of Justine's own declaration of guilt, and that nothing but Justine's own confession could shake her confidence.

Justine then admitted to confessing, but revealed it was a lie, coerced from her so she might obtain absolution; this falsehood, she said, now weighed more heavily on her heart than all her other sins.
She explained that her confessor had relentlessly besieged her since her condemnation, threatening and menacing her until she almost began to believe she was the monster he portrayed.
He had threatened excommunication and hellfire in her final moments if she remained obstinate.

Feeling utterly unsupported and viewed by all as a wretch doomed to infamy and perdition, Justine explained that in an evil hour, she had succumbed and agreed to the lie, which now made her truly miserable.

events.text_segment:
Soon after we heard that the poor victim had expressed a desire to see my cousin. My father wished her not to go but said that he left it to her own judgment and feelings to decide. “Yes,” said Elizabeth, “I will go, although she is guilty; and you, Victor, shall accompany me; I cannot go alone.” The idea of this visit was torture to me, yet I could not refuse.
We entered the gloomy prison chamber and beheld Justine sitting on some straw at the farther end; her hands were manacled, and her head rested on her knees. She rose on seeing us enter, and when we were left alone with her, she threw herself at the feet of Elizabeth, weeping bitterly. My cousin wept also.
“Oh, Justine!” said she. “Why did you rob me of my last consolation? I relied on your innocence, and although I was then very wretched, I was not so miserable as I am now.”
“And do you also believe that I am so very, very wicked? Do you also join with my enemies to crush me, to condemn me as a murderer?” Her voice was suffocated with sobs.
“Rise, my poor girl,” said Elizabeth; “why do you kneel, if you are innocent? I am not one of your enemies, I believed you guiltless, notwithstanding every evidence, until I heard that you had yourself declared your guilt. That report, you say, is false; and be assured, dear Justine, that nothing can shake my confidence in you for a moment, but your own confession.”
“I did confess, but I confessed a lie. I confessed, that I might obtain absolution; but now that falsehood lies heavier at my heart than all my other sins. The God of heaven forgive me! Ever since I was condemned, my confessor has besieged me; he threatened and menaced, until I almost began to think that I was the monster that he said I was. He threatened excommunication and hell fire in my last moments if I continued obdurate. Dear lady, I had none to support me; all looked on me as a wretch doomed to ignominy and perdition. What could I do? In an evil hour I subscribed to a lie; and now only am I truly miserable.”

events.title: Resignation and Remorse: Justine's Peace and Victor's Inner Hell
detailed_summary: Continuing through her tears, Justine expressed her horror at the thought that Elizabeth might believe her capable of such a diabolical crime, especially given the high esteem in which Elizabeth's late aunt and Elizabeth herself had held her.
She spoke of finding solace in the thought of soon seeing dear William in heaven, where they would all be happy, a comfort as she faced ignominy and death.

Elizabeth, filled with remorse for her momentary distrust, begged Justine's forgiveness and vehemently declared she would proclaim and prove Justine's innocence, vowing to melt the hearts of her enemies with tears and prayers, insisting Justine would not die.
Justine mournfully shook her head, stating she no longer feared death, as that pang had passed, and God provided her with the courage to endure the worst.
She described the world as sad and bitter, and expressed resignation to her fate, provided Elizabeth remembered her as unjustly condemned, advising Elizabeth to patiently submit to heaven's will.
During this exchange, Victor had retreated to a corner of the prison room, consumed by a horrid anguish he felt surpassed even Justine's suffering.
He gnashed his teeth and groaned from his soul, causing Justine to startle; when she saw him, she approached and kindly thanked him for visiting, expressing hope that he did not believe her guilty.
Elizabeth interjected, assuring Justine that Victor was even more convinced of her innocence than she had been, not crediting the confession even when he heard of it.

Justine expressed sincere gratitude, saying that the kindness of those who believed in her innocence removed more than half her misfortune and allowed her to feel she could die in peace now that her innocence was acknowledged by Elizabeth and Victor.

While the poor sufferer, Justine, tried to comfort others and herself, achieving a desired resignation, Victor, the true murderer, felt an unceasing, living torment in his heart, devoid of hope or consolation.

Elizabeth also wept and was unhappy, but her misery was that of innocence, a temporary shadow, whereas Victor's anguish and despair had deeply penetrated his core, creating an unquenchable hell within him.

events.text_segment:
She paused, weeping, and then continued, “I thought with horror, my sweet lady, that you should believe your Justine, whom your blessed aunt had so highly honoured, and whom you loved, was a creature capable of a crime which none but the devil himself could have perpetrated. Dear William! dearest blessed child! I soon shall see you again in heaven, where we shall all be happy; and that consoles me, going as I am to suffer ignominy and death.”
“Oh, Justine! Forgive me for having for one moment distrusted you. Why did you confess? But do not mourn, dear girl. Do not fear. I will proclaim, I will prove your innocence. I will melt the stony hearts of your enemies by my tears and prayers. You shall not die! You, my playfellow, my companion, my sister, perish on the scaffold! No! No! I never could survive so horrible a misfortune.”
Justine shook her head mournfully. “I do not fear to die,” she said; “that pang is past. God raises my weakness and gives me courage to endure the worst. I leave a sad and bitter world; and if you remember me and think of me as of one unjustly condemned, I am resigned to the fate awaiting me. Learn from me, dear lady, to submit in patience to the will of heaven!”
During this conversation I had retired to a corner of the prison room, where I could conceal the horrid anguish that possessed me. Despair! Who dared talk of that? The poor victim, who on the morrow was to pass the awful boundary between life and death, felt not, as I did, such deep and bitter agony. I gnashed my teeth and ground them together, uttering a groan that came from my inmost soul. Justine started. When she saw who it was, she approached me and said, “Dear sir, you are very kind to visit me; you, I hope, do not believe that I am guilty?”
I could not answer. “No, Justine,” said Elizabeth; “he is more convinced of your innocence than I was, for even when he heard that you had confessed, he did not credit it.”
“I truly thank him. In these last moments I feel the sincerest gratitude towards those who think of me with kindness. How sweet is the affection of others to such a wretch as I am! It removes more than half my misfortune, and I feel as if I could die in peace now that my innocence is acknowledged by you, dear lady, and your cousin.”
Thus the poor sufferer tried to comfort others and herself. She indeed gained the resignation she desired. But I, the true murderer, felt the never-dying worm alive in my bosom, which allowed of no hope or consolation. Elizabeth also wept and was unhappy, but hers also was the misery of innocence, which, like a cloud that passes over the fair moon, for a while hides but cannot tarnish its brightness. Anguish and despair had penetrated into the core of my heart; I bore a hell within me which nothing could extinguish.

I am leaving a sorrowful and bitter existence; and if you remember me and consider me someone wrongly condemned, I accept the fate awaiting me. Please, dear lady, learn from my example to patiently yield to divine will!” Throughout this exchange, I had retreated to a corner of the prison chamber, where I could hide the awful torment consuming me. Despair! Who dared even utter the word? The poor victim, who was set to cross the terrifying threshold between life and death the next day, did not feel the deep and agonizing pain that I did. I clenched my teeth and ground them together, letting out a groan that came from the very depths of my being. Justine was startled. Seeing who it was, she came over and said, “My dear sir, it is very kind of you to visit me; I hope you, too, do not believe I am guilty?” I could not speak. “No, Justine,” Elizabeth said; “he is even more certain of your innocence than I was, because he refused to believe it even when he heard you had confessed.” “I am truly grateful to him. In these final moments, I feel the deepest thankfulness towards those who regard me with kindness. How precious is the affection of others to a wretch like myself! It alleviates more than half of my misery, and I feel as though I could die in peace now that my innocence is acknowledged by you, dear lady, and your cousin.” Thus, the poor sufferer attempted to comfort herself and those around her. Indeed, she attained the composure she sought. But I, the true killer, felt the ceaseless torment gnawing within my chest, offering no hope or solace. Elizabeth also wept and was unhappy, but her suffering was the grief of an innocent heart, which, like a cloud passing over a bright moon, temporarily obscures but cannot diminish its radiance. Anguish and hopelessness had pierced the very core of my heart; I carried a hell within me that nothing could extinguish.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14:
She stopped in tears before going on: "I was horrified, my dear lady, that you might think your faithful Justine—trusted so much by your beloved aunt and loved by you—capable of a crime only the devil could commit. Sweet William! Dearest child! I will soon see you again in heaven, where we will all be happy together; the thought comforts me as I face shame and death." 

"Oh, Justine! Please forgive me for doubting you, even for a moment. Why did you confess? But don’t despair, dear girl. Don’t be afraid. I’ll make everyone know, I’ll prove you are innocent. I’ll move your enemies to pity with my tears and pleas. You won’t die! My childhood friend and companion, my sister, you can’t possibly be executed! No! I couldn’t bear such horror."

Justine sadly shook her head. "I am not afraid of death anymore," she said. "That fear has faded. God gives me strength to endure what is coming. I leave a harsh and painful world; if you remember me as someone wrongly condemned, I can accept my fate. Let me be an example to you, my dear friend, to patiently accept God’s will."

During all this, I retreated to a dark corner of the prison cell to hide my overwhelming anguish. Despair—who could truly speak of it? The poor victim, about to cross the dreadful border between life and death, did not feel the same bitter agony I did. Grinding my teeth, I let out a groan from deep inside me. Justine jumped, but when she saw it was me, she came over. "Kind sir, thank you for coming. I hope you don’t believe I am guilty?"

I was unable to respond. Elizabeth said, "No, Justine, he is even more certain of your innocence than I was. Even after you confessed, he didn’t believe it."

"I truly thank him. In my last moments, I am so grateful to those who are kind to me. The affection of others softens more than half my suffering. I feel at peace now that you and your cousin acknowledge my innocence."

So Justine did her best to give comfort to others and herself, and she truly found the resignation she wanted. But I, the real murderer, felt a torment inside me that could never be ended. Elizabeth cried and was miserable too, but her suffering was the pain of an innocent, which, like a passing cloud over the bright moon, briefly hides but does not dull its light. But my heart was filled with absolute pain and despair; I carried a hell inside me that nothing could put out.

events.title: Final Farewell and Tragic End: Justine's Execution
detailed_summary: Victor and Elizabeth remained with Justine for several more hours, and Elizabeth found it immensely difficult to depart.
Elizabeth cried out, wishing she could die with Justine, unable to endure living in such a miserable world.
Justine, while struggling to repress her own bitter tears, put on an air of cheerfulness.

She embraced Elizabeth and, in a voice thick with suppressed emotion, bid her farewell, calling her her sweet lady, dearest friend, and beloved companion, praying for heaven's blessing and preservation upon her, and hoping this would be Elizabeth's last misfortune, urging her to live, be happy, and make others happy.
The following day, Justine was executed.
Elizabeth's heart-wrenching eloquence had been insufficient to persuade the judges from their firm conviction of the saintly sufferer's criminality.
Victor's own passionate and indignant appeals were equally ignored by them.

Upon receiving their cold responses and hearing the harsh, unfeeling reasoning of these men, Victor's intended confession died on his lips, realizing that such an avowal would only lead to him being declared a madman, without revoking the sentence passed on his wretched victim.
Justine died on the scaffold, branded as a murderess.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She perished on the scaffold as a murderess!

events.text_segment:
We stayed several hours with Justine, and it was with great difficulty that Elizabeth could tear herself away. “I wish,” cried she, “that I were to die with you; I cannot live in this world of misery.”
Justine assumed an air of cheerfulness, while she with difficulty repressed her bitter tears. She embraced Elizabeth and said in a voice of half-suppressed emotion, “Farewell, sweet lady, dearest Elizabeth, my beloved and only friend; may heaven, in its bounty, bless and preserve you; may this be the last misfortune that you will ever suffer! Live, and be happy, and make others so.”
And on the morrow Justine died. Elizabeth’s heart-rending eloquence failed to move the judges from their settled conviction in the criminality of the saintly sufferer. My passionate and indignant appeals were lost upon them. And when I received their cold answers and heard the harsh, unfeeling reasoning of these men, my purposed avowal died away on my lips. Thus I might proclaim myself a madman, but not revoke the sentence passed upon my wretched victim. She perished on the scaffold as a murderess!

The following day, Justine was executed. Elizabeth's powerful and emotionally charged pleas could not convince the judges to change their minds about the guilt of the seemingly innocent woman. My own impassioned and furious arguments were likewise ineffective. When I received their unsympathetic responses and heard their harsh, unfeeling reasoning, the confession I had intended to make remained unsaid. I understood that I would only be seen as insane without being able to reverse the sentence pronounced upon my unfortunate victim. She was put to death on the scaffold, branded a murderess!

events.title: Prophetic Despair: Victor's Guilt and the Shadow of Future Sorrows
detailed_summary: Turning from his own inner torments, Victor observed Elizabeth's profound and silent grief, recognizing it as yet another consequence of his actions.
He acknowledged that his father's sorrow and the desolation of their once joyful home were all the work of his own
thrice-accursed hands.
In an internal monologue, he addressed his grieving loved ones, foretelling that their current tears were not their last and that more sounds of lamentation would surely follow.

He, Frankenstein—their son, kinsman, and devoted friend who would sacrifice his life for them and found joy only in their happiness—bade them weep countless tears, hoping that perhaps this suffering might appease an inexorable fate and halt further destruction before death brought them peace from their torments.
This premonition, which he attributed to his
prophetic soul,
arose from his overwhelming remorse, horror, and despair as he watched his beloved family mourn William and Justine.
He identified William and Justine as the initial, unfortunate casualties of his
unhallowed arts.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: From the tortures of my own heart, I turned to contemplate the deep and voiceless grief of my Elizabeth.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Thus spoke my prophetic soul, as, torn by remorse, horror, and despair, I beheld those I loved spend vain sorrow upon the graves of William and Justine, the first hapless victims to my unhallowed arts.

events.text_segment:
From the tortures of my own heart, I turned to contemplate the deep and voiceless grief of my Elizabeth. This also was my doing! And my father’s woe, and the desolation of that late so smiling home all was the work of my thrice-accursed hands! Ye weep, unhappy ones, but these are not your last tears! Again shall you raise the funeral wail, and the sound of your lamentations shall again and again be heard! Frankenstein, your son, your kinsman, your early, much-loved friend; he who would spend each vital drop of blood for your sakes, who has no thought nor sense of joy except as it is mirrored also in your dear countenances, who would fill the air with blessings and spend his life in serving you—he bids you weep, to shed countless tears; happy beyond his hopes, if thus inexorable fate be satisfied, and if the destruction pause before the peace of the grave have succeeded to your sad torments!
Thus spoke my prophetic soul, as, torn by remorse, horror, and despair, I beheld those I loved spend vain sorrow upon the graves of William and Justine, the first hapless victims to my unhallowed arts.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Turning away from my own profound anguish, I contemplated the deep, unspoken sorrow of my Elizabeth. This, too, was my doing! And my father's grief, and the ruin of that home which was so cheerful until recently—all of it was the result of my utterly cursed actions! You mourn, unhappy souls, but these are not the last tears you will shed! Again you will weep at funerals, and your cries of lamentation will be heard repeatedly! Frankenstein, your son, your relative, your dear friend from long ago—the one who would give every last drop of his lifeblood for your sakes, who finds joy only when reflected in your beloved faces, who would shower you with blessings and devote his life to serving you—he now causes you to weep, to shed countless tears; he would be incredibly fortunate if, by this immense suffering, relentless fate were satisfied, and destruction would halt before the peace of the grave finally provides relief from your painful torments!
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Tormented by my own emotional pain, I began to focus on the silent, profound sorrow felt by Elizabeth. I realized that I was to blame for her suffering as well as my father's distress and the misery that had overtaken our once joyful home—all of it was caused by my actions. You mourn now, my unfortunate loved ones, but these tears are not the last you will shed. Once more you will grieve at funerals, and your cries of sorrow will echo repeatedly. Frankenstein—your son, your relative, your old and dearly-loved friend—who would do anything for you and finds happiness only in your happiness, now brings you only reason to weep and shed endless tears. If endless grief is what fate demands and if your suffering may cease only with death, then so be it. These were the thoughts that filled my mind, prophesying doom, as I watched those I loved waste their sorrow on the graves of William and Justine, the first innocent victims of the terrible things I had created.

events.title: Victor's Crushing Guilt and Self-Imposed Isolation
detailed_summary: Victor describes the profound mental anguish following a period of intense events, specifically the certainty of Justine's death, which leaves him in a state devoid of hope or fear but filled with despair.
Despite the physical vitality of his body, his heart is weighed down by an unshakeable burden of despair and remorse.
Sleep evades him, and he wanders as if an accursed spirit, tormented by the horrific deeds he believes he has caused and fearing more to come.
He reflects on his initially benevolent intentions and his desire to be useful to humanity, contrasting it with his current blasted state and the loss of self-satisfaction.
His conscience is replaced by an overwhelming remorse and guilt, thrusting him into an indescribable hell of torment.
This mental suffering takes a toll on his physical health, which had not fully recovered from previous shocks.
He actively avoids human interaction, finding any expression of joy or contentment unbearable, and seeks refuge only in profound, death-like solitude.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Nothing is more painful to the human mind than, after the feelings have been worked up by a quick succession of events, the dead calmness of inaction and certainty which follows and deprives the soul both of hope and fear.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I shunned the face of man; all sound of joy or complacency was torture to me; solitude was my only consolation—deep, dark, deathlike solitude.

events.text_segment:
Nothing is more painful to the human mind than, after the feelings have been worked up by a quick succession of events, the dead calmness of inaction and certainty which follows and deprives the soul both of hope and fear. Justine died, she rested, and I was alive. The blood flowed freely in my veins, but a weight of despair and remorse pressed on my heart which nothing could remove. Sleep fled from my eyes; I wandered like an evil spirit, for I had committed deeds of mischief beyond description horrible, and more, much more (I persuaded myself) was yet behind. Yet my heart overflowed with kindness and the love of virtue. I had begun life with benevolent intentions and thirsted for the moment when I should put them in practice and make myself useful to my fellow beings. Now all was blasted; instead of that serenity of conscience which allowed me to look back upon the past with self-satisfaction, and from thence to gather promise of new hopes, I was seized by remorse and the sense of guilt, which hurried me away to a hell of intense tortures such as no language can describe.
This state of mind preyed upon my health, which had perhaps never entirely recovered from the first shock it had sustained. I shunned the face of man; all sound of joy or complacency was torture to me; solitude was my only consolation—deep, dark, deathlike solitude.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Transitioning from a rapid series of emotionally charged events to a state of passive calm and inescapable certainty is profoundly agonizing for the human psyche, stripping away both anticipation and apprehension. Following Justine's death, she found peace, while I remained alive. Though my body functioned normally, a crushing burden of guilt and despair weighed on my heart, impossible to lift. Sleep evaded me; I roamed like a cursed entity, having committed acts of unspeakable horror, and convinced myself that even greater terrible deeds were yet to come. Despite this, my heart was filled with benevolence and a desire for virtue. I had started life with good intentions, eager for the chance to act on them and contribute positively to society. Now, everything was ruined; instead of the clear conscience that let me reflect on the past with satisfaction and look forward with renewed hope, I was consumed by overwhelming guilt and remorse, plunging me into an unbearable, indescribable agony. This mental anguish severely impacted my health, which had likely never fully recovered from the initial trauma. I avoided human contact; any sign of happiness or contentment caused me pain; only solitude offered comfort—a profound, bleak, lifeless solitude.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Few things are more agonizing to the human mind than the numb inactivity and harsh certainty that comes after a rapid string of emotional events, leaving the soul stripped of both hope and fear. While Justine found her rest in death, I remained alive, burdened with flowing blood but also with an overwhelming despair and guilt that nothing could lift. I could not find sleep; I wandered aimlessly like a tormented spirit, haunted by unspeakable misdeeds that I had committed, and I believed that even worse was yet to come. Still, my heart was full of kindness and a desire for goodness. I had started life with generous intentions, eager for the chance to help others. Now all those dreams were ruined; instead of a clear conscience allowing me to reflect on the past with pride and find hope for the future, I was overcome with remorse and guilt, driving me into a torturous misery that words could not capture. This mental anguish affected my health, which perhaps had never fully recovered from its earlier trauma. I avoided other people; any sounds of happiness or contentment were painful to me, and I found solace only in deep, dark, lifeless isolation.

events.title: Father's Unheeded Counsel
detailed_summary: Victor's father, pained by the noticeable change in his son's demeanor and habits, attempts to encourage him.
Drawing from his own clear conscience and virtuous life, he tries to instill fortitude in Victor and motivate him to overcome his gloom.
He questions Victor, sharing his own suffering over William's death, yet emphasizing the responsibility to the living to avoid amplifying their sorrow with excessive grief.
He further argues that such deep sorrow is a disservice to oneself, hindering personal growth, enjoyment, and the ability to perform daily duties essential for societal participation.
Victor acknowledges the wisdom of his father's advice but finds it utterly irrelevant to his own unique situation, where remorse and terror intensify his grief.
Unable to articulate his true reasons, Victor can only respond to his father with a look of utter despair and an attempt to withdraw from his sight.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: My father observed with pain the alteration perceptible in my disposition and habits and endeavoured by arguments deduced from the feelings of his serene conscience and guiltless life to inspire me with fortitude and awaken in me the courage to dispel the dark cloud which brooded over me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Now I could only answer my father with a look of despair and endeavour to hide myself from his view.

events.text_segment:
My father observed with pain the alteration perceptible in my disposition and habits and endeavoured by arguments deduced from the feelings of his serene conscience and guiltless life to inspire me with fortitude and awaken in me the courage to dispel the dark cloud which brooded over me. “Do you think, Victor,” said he, “that I do not suffer also? No one could love a child more than I loved your brother”—tears came into his eyes as he spoke—“but is it not a duty to the survivors that we should refrain from augmenting their unhappiness by an appearance of immoderate grief? It is also a duty owed to yourself, for excessive sorrow prevents improvement or enjoyment, or even the discharge of daily usefulness, without which no man is fit for society.”
This advice, although good, was totally inapplicable to my case; I should have been the first to hide my grief and console my friends if remorse had not mingled its bitterness, and terror its alarm, with my other sensations. Now I could only answer my father with a look of despair and endeavour to hide myself from his view.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: My father sadly noticed the clear changes in my mood and behaviour. He tried to encourage me and give me the strength to overcome my sadness, using reasons based on his own peaceful conscience and blameless life. He said, "Victor, do you imagine I'm not suffering too? No one could have loved a child more than I loved your brother," his eyes filling with tears as he spoke. "But don't we survivors have a responsibility to avoid increasing the misery of others by displaying excessive sorrow? You also owe it to yourself, because overwhelming grief prevents personal growth, happiness, or even performing essential daily tasks, which are necessary for participating in society." Although his counsel was sound, it was completely unsuitable for my situation; I would have readily concealed my sorrow and comforted my friends, had my feelings not been tainted by the harshness of guilt and the fearfulness of terror. As it was, I could only respond to my father with a look of hopelessness and try to keep myself from his sight.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: My father sadly noticed the change in my behavior and way of life, and tried to encourage me to be brave and lift myself out of my despair, using arguments based on his own clear conscience and pure life. "Victor," he said, "do you think I am unaffected by this? No one could have loved your brother more than I did." Tears filled his eyes as he continued, "But isn't it important, for the sake of those still living, not to deepen their sadness by showing too much grief? We also owe it to ourselves, since too much sorrow keeps us from moving forward, enjoying life, or fulfilling our daily responsibilities, which are essential for anyone to function in society." Although this was wise advice, it didn't apply to my situation. If I hadn't been consumed by guilt and fear along with my grief, I would have been the first to conceal my sorrow and comfort others. Now, all I could do was look at my father in despair and try to avoid his gaze.

events.title: Troubled Solace and Suicidal Contemplation at Belrive
detailed_summary: The family relocates to their home in Belrive, a change Victor finds agreeable as it offers more freedom than their Geneva residence.
He frequently takes solitary boat trips on the lake late at night after his family has gone to bed.
Sometimes he sails with the wind, other times he rows to the middle of the lake and lets the boat drift, surrendering to his miserable thoughts.
In the tranquility of these scenes, feeling like the sole unquiet being, he often feels a strong temptation to drown himself and end his suffering.
However, thoughts of the heroic and suffering Elizabeth, whom he deeply loves and whose life is intertwined with his, restrain him.
He also considers his father and surviving brother, questioning if he could abandon them to the mercy of the monster he unleashed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: About this time we retired to our house at Belrive.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Should I by my base desertion leave them exposed and unprotected to the malice of the fiend whom I had let loose among them?

events.text_segment: About this time we retired to our house at Belrive. This change was particularly agreeable to me. The shutting of the gates regularly at ten o’clock and the impossibility of remaining on the lake after that hour had rendered our residence within the walls of Geneva very irksome to me. I was now free. Often, after the rest of the family had retired for the night, I took the boat and passed many hours upon the water. Sometimes, with my sails set, I was carried by the wind; and sometimes, after rowing into the middle of the lake, I left the boat to pursue its own course and gave way to my own miserable reflections. I was often tempted, when all was at peace around me, and I the only unquiet thing that wandered restless in a scene so beautiful and heavenly—if I except some bat, or the frogs, whose harsh and interrupted croaking was heard only when I approached the shore—often, I say, I was tempted to plunge into the silent lake, that the waters might close over me and my calamities for ever. But I was restrained, when I thought of the heroic and suffering Elizabeth, whom I tenderly loved, and whose existence was bound up in mine. I thought also of my father and surviving brother; should I by my base desertion leave them exposed and unprotected to the malice of the fiend whom I had let loose among them?
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Around this time, we relocated to our home in Belrive. This change was particularly welcome to me. Being confined within Geneva's walls felt oppressive due to the strict ten o'clock gate closure and the inability to be on the lake after that hour. Now, I felt liberated. Frequently, after my family had retired for the night, I would take a boat and spend several hours on the water. At times, I would sail wherever the wind took me; other times, after rowing to the center, I would let the boat drift aimlessly while I succumbed to my own sorrowful thoughts. Often, surrounded by perfect peace, feeling like the sole troubled soul wandering restlessly in such a beautiful, serene setting—aside, perhaps, from a bat or the frogs whose rough, broken croaks were only audible near the shore—I was strongly tempted to leap into the silent lake, allowing the water to cover me and end my miseries forever. However, I held back when I considered the noble, suffering Elizabeth, whom I deeply cherished and whose life was connected to mine. I also thought of my father and remaining brother; could I possibly abandon them so basely, leaving them exposed and unprotected from the malevolent creature I had unleashed upon them?
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: Around this time, we moved to our house at Belrive, a change I greatly enjoyed. In Geneva, the city gates closed every night at ten, making it impossible to stay out on the lake late, which had made living there unpleasant for me. Now, I felt liberated. Frequently, after my family went to bed, I would take the boat out and spend long hours on the lake. Sometimes, I'd sail with the wind; other times, I’d row into the center and let the boat drift while I lost myself in sorrowful thoughts. events.title: Consuming Hatred and Pervasive Fear of the Monster
detailed_summary: During moments of intense despair, Victor weeps and wishes for mental peace, not for himself, but so he could bring comfort to his loved ones.
However, remorse obliterates any such hope, as he feels responsible for irreversible evils.
He lives in constant, daily fear that the monster he created will commit new acts of wickedness.
An obscure premonition tells him that the horror is not over and that the creature will perpetrate a crime so enormous it would overshadow past events.
He feels that as long as anyone he loves remains, there will always be a reason for fear.
His hatred for the fiend is indescribable; thoughts of it cause him to gnash his teeth and his eyes to become inflamed, fueling an ardent wish to destroy the life he so carelessly created.
Reflecting on the monster's crimes and malice, his desire for hatred and revenge surpasses all moderation.
He imagines undertaking an arduous journey to the Andes just for the chance to cast the monster from their highest peak.
He desperately wants to encounter the monster again to unleash his full abhorrence upon it and avenge William and Justine.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At these moments I wept bitterly and wished that peace would revisit my mind only that I might afford them consolation and happiness.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I wished to see him again, that I might wreak the utmost extent of abhorrence on his head and avenge the deaths of William and Justine.

events.text_segment: At these moments I wept bitterly and wished that peace would revisit my mind only that I might afford them consolation and happiness. But that could not be. Remorse extinguished every hope. I had been the author of unalterable evils, and I lived in daily fear lest the monster whom I had created should perpetrate some new wickedness. I had an obscure feeling that all was not over and that he would still commit some signal crime, which by its enormity should almost efface the recollection of the past. There was always scope for fear so long as anything I loved remained behind. My abhorrence of this fiend cannot be conceived. When I thought of him I gnashed my teeth, my eyes became inflamed, and I ardently wished to extinguish that life which I had so thoughtlessly bestowed. When I reflected on his crimes and malice, my hatred and revenge burst all bounds of moderation. I would have made a pilgrimage to the highest peak of the Andes, could I, when there, have precipitated him to their base. I wished to see him again, that I might wreak the utmost extent of abhorrence on his head and avenge the deaths of William and Justine.

But that wasn't possible. Guilt had extinguished all my hope. I was responsible for irreparable harm, and I lived in perpetual fear that the creature I had made would commit yet another wicked act. I had a vague premonition that things were not finished and that he would still perform some notable crime, one whose sheer horror would almost overshadow the memory of his past deeds. There would always be cause for fear as long as anyone I loved remained alive. My intense detestation for this monster is unimaginable. When I thought of him, I ground my teeth, my eyes became inflamed, and I intensely desired to end the life I had so thoughtlessly granted. When I reflected on his crimes and malevolence, my hatred and thirst for revenge knew no bounds of moderation. I would have traveled to the highest summit of the Andes, if only I could have hurled him from its peak upon reaching it. I wished to see him again so I could unleash the full extent of my abhorrence upon him and seek retribution for the deaths of William and Justine.
events.paraphrase_gpt-4.1-2025-04-14: During these times, I cried deeply and longed for peace to return to my thoughts, hoping that I might be able to bring comfort and joy to others. But this was impossible. My remorse destroyed any hope I had. events.title: A Household Draped in Mourning and Elizabeth's Changed Demeanor
detailed_summary: The Frankenstein home is characterized by pervasive grief.
Victor's father's health is severely affected by the horror of the recent tragic events.
Elizabeth is melancholic and despondent, finding no joy in her usual pastimes.
She perceives any form of pleasure as disrespectful to the deceased, believing that perpetual sorrow and tears are the only fitting tribute to such cruelly destroyed innocence.
She is no longer the cheerful young woman who once wandered with Victor by the lake, enthusiastically discussing their future.
The narrative notes that a profound sorrow, the kind that begins to detach one from worldly joys, has touched her, extinguishing her brightest smiles.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Our house was the house of mourning.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The first of those sorrows which are sent to wean us from the earth had visited her, and its dimming influence quenched her dearest smiles.

events.text_segment: Our house was the house of mourning. My father’s health was deeply shaken by the horror of the recent events. Elizabeth was sad and desponding; she no longer took delight in her ordinary occupations; all pleasure seemed to her sacrilege toward the dead; eternal woe and tears she then thought was the just tribute she should pay to innocence so blasted and destroyed. She was no longer that happy creature who in earlier youth wandered with me on the banks of the lake and talked with ecstasy of our future prospects. The first of those sorrows which are sent to wean us from the earth had visited her, and its dimming influence quenched her dearest smiles.
events.paraphrase_gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-1: Our home was consumed by grief. The recent dreadful events had a severe impact on my father's health. Elizabeth was overcome with sadness and despair; she no longer found joy in her customary activities. She felt that any pleasure was a sacrilege against the deceased, and she believed that endless sorrow and tears were the appropriate tribute for innocence so tragically ruined and destroyed. She was a stark contrast to the happy person she had been in her youth, when she roamed with me along the lake's edge and enthusiastically discussed our future hopes. This was her first significant sorrow, the type that serves to lessen our attachment to worldly concerns, and its darkening effect extinguished her most cherished smiles.

events.title: Elizabeth's Despair over Injustice and Her Plea to Victor
detailed_summary: Elizabeth confides in Victor that Justine Moritz's tragic death has profoundly altered her perception of the world.
Previously, accounts of vice and injustice seemed like distant tales, but now, with misery so close, people appear to her as bloodthirsty monsters.
She acknowledges this view might be unjust, reflecting on how everyone believed Justine guilty, and how depraved Justine would have been if she had committed the crime.
She asserts her firm belief in Justine's innocence, a conviction strengthened by Victor's agreement.
Elizabeth questions the nature of happiness when falsehood can so convincingly mimic truth, feeling as though she's on a precipice with many trying to push her into an abyss.
She laments that William and Justine were murdered while their killer roams free, possibly respected, stating she would rather die on the scaffold than be such a wretch.
Listening to her words causes Victor extreme agony, as he knows he is, in effect, the true murderer.
Elizabeth, noticing his anguish and the despair and revenge in his expression, gently takes his hand and implores him to calm himself.
She shares her own deep sorrow but notes Victor's wretchedness is greater, urging him to banish his dark passions and remember his friends who place all their hopes in him.
She appeals to their love and mutual fidelity, suggesting that in their peaceful and beautiful native land, they can still find tranquility and happiness.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “When I reflect, my dear cousin,” said she, “on the miserable death of Justine Moritz, I no longer see the world and its works as they before appeared to me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Ah! While we love, while we are true to each other, here in this land of peace and beauty, your native country, we may reap every tranquil blessing—what can disturb our peace?”

events.text_segment:
“When I reflect, my dear cousin,” said she, “on the miserable death of Justine Moritz, I no longer see the world and its works as they before appeared to me. Before, I looked upon the accounts of vice and injustice that I read in books or heard from others as tales of ancient days or imaginary evils; at least they were remote and more familiar to reason than to the imagination; but now misery has come home, and men appear to me as monsters thirsting for each other’s blood. Yet I am certainly unjust. Everybody believed that poor girl to be guilty; and if she could have committed the crime for which she suffered, assuredly she would have been the most depraved of human creatures. For the sake of a few jewels, to have murdered the son of her benefactor and friend, a child whom she had nursed from its birth, and appeared to love as if it had been her own! I could not consent to the death of any human being, but certainly I should have thought such a creature unfit to remain in the society of men. But she was innocent. I know, I feel she was innocent; you are of the same opinion, and that confirms me. Alas! Victor, when falsehood can look so like the truth, who can assure themselves of certain happiness? I feel as if I were walking on the edge of a precipice, towards which thousands are crowding and endeavouring to plunge me into the abyss. William and Justine were assassinated, and the murderer escapes; he walks about the world free, and perhaps respected. But even if I were condemned to suffer on the scaffold for the same crimes, I would not change places with such a wretch.”
I listened to this discourse with the extremest agony. I, not in deed, but in effect, was the true murderer. Elizabeth read my anguish in my countenance, and kindly taking my hand, said, “My dearest friend, you must calm yourself. These events have affected me, God knows how deeply; but I am not so wretched as you are. There is an expression of despair, and sometimes of revenge, in your countenance that makes me tremble. Dear Victor, banish these dark passions. Remember the friends around you, who centre all their hopes in you. Have we lost the power of rendering you happy? Ah! While we love, while we are true to each other, here in this land of peace and beauty, your native country, we may reap every tranquil blessing—what can disturb our peace?”

Yet, she firmly believed Justine was innocent, stating she knew it and felt it, and that my agreement confirmed her conviction. She felt as though she were precariously balanced on the edge of a cliff, with countless people trying to push her into the abyss. events.title: Victor's Unyielding Despair Despite Elizabeth's Comfort
detailed_summary: Victor questions inwardly whether Elizabeth's words, from someone he cherishes deeply, could dispel the darkness in his heart.
As she speaks, he draws closer to her, as if terrified that the destroyer might appear at that very moment to take her from him.
He concludes that neither the tenderness of friendship, nor the beauty of the earth or sky, can rescue his soul from its misery; even loving words are ineffective.
He feels entirely enveloped by a cloud of despair that no positive influence can penetrate.
He likens himself to a mortally wounded deer, retreating to a secluded spot to gaze at its fatal injury and die.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And could not such words from her whom I fondly prized before every other gift of fortune suffice to chase away the fiend that lurked in my heart?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The wounded deer dragging its fainting limbs to some untrodden brake, there to gaze upon the arrow which had pierced it, and to die, was but a type of me.

events.text_segment:
And could not such words from her whom I fondly prized before every other gift of fortune suffice to chase away the fiend that lurked in my heart? Even as she spoke I drew near to her, as if in terror, lest at that very moment the destroyer had been near to rob me of her.
Thus not the tenderness of friendship, nor the beauty of earth, nor of heaven, could redeem my soul from woe; the very accents of love were ineffectual. I was encompassed by a cloud which no beneficial influence could penetrate. The wounded deer dragging its fainting limbs to some untrodden brake, there to gaze upon the arrow which had pierced it, and to die, was but a type of me.
